video.title: The Best, Worst and Blandest of 2024 | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Well, Merry Christmas and a Happy New—STOP 
STALLING WITH YOUR ASININE PLEASANTRIES,

YOU MASSIVE TWAT. Put us out of our misery and 
tell us about some good games from 2024 that

aren&#39;t Arsing Astro Bloody Bot. I know, right? I&#39;m 
surprised the Game Awards even had time to give

Hideo Kojima his customary kiss on the bellend 
with all the time it was spending climbing up

and down Astro Bot&#39;s dick. Alright, fine. Without 
further ado, let&#39;s distract ourselves from Sony&#39;s

autofellatio habits with the customary Fully 
Ramblomatic Top 5, Bottom 5, and Blandest 5

for the year 2024. Starting as always with 
fifth best, which is—oh, for Christ&#39;s sake.

Yes, alright, it might represent Sony 
smarmily jerking off over a back catalogue

that it itself has mostly banished to the 
non-backwards compatible black hole of buggery,

but get past all that and it&#39;s a fun, well 
designed platformer with impressive tech. So

here&#39;s another little prize for it that 
it can use to hold the door open while

it&#39;s bringing in Geoff Keighley&#39;s 
industrial-sized blowjob machine.

As always, games become shoe-ins for 
the bland list whenever I struggle

to remember anything that happened in 
them, so here&#39;s Phantom Fury. Actually,
I remember one thing: I remember a 90s-style

wacky fun retro shooter trying to simultaneously 
be a 2000s-style chin-strokey depressing shooter

and ending up a great big empty spunk bubble that 
doesn&#39;t belong anywhere. Except in some spunk.

More and more, Nintendo&#39;s output has been 
reflecting a sort of &quot;We&#39;re number 1,

so why try harder?&quot; attitude, 
mainly in Pokémon games,

but that vibe&#39;s definitely crept into Echoes 
of Wisdom. Spicing up the Zelda franchise

is gonna take more than doing the same shit 
as always but with the debug tools left on,

especially when the design numbers 
add up like a presidential tax return.

Concluding the &quot;yes, alright, the Game Awards 
get it right sometimes&quot; component of the top 5,

Metaphor: ReFer to my previous email is a 
stylish Persona-adjacent fantasy romp let

down just a little by being a bit dry and 
a bit standard as far as JRPG settings go,
angry democracy sky dad notwithstanding.

Apparently, Dragon Age: Veilguard went through 
a lot of reworking, even being envisioned as

an online live service at some point, hence 
the trailer looking more like a hero shooter

than most hero shooters do. Whatever the case, the 
final game certainly does give off a strong vibe

of being uncomfortable in its own skin. Like 
an uncircumcised penis with claustrophobia.

The more I think about Slitterhead, 
the less I like it in retrospect. Yes,

it&#39;s got ideas and evokes the creativity 
golden age of the PS2 era, but I think even

back then I&#39;d have said the same thing about 
it, to wit: &quot;Fighting the weirdly talkative

praying mantis dude wasn&#39;t particularly scary or 
interesting the first 19 times you made me do it.&quot;

There&#39;s only one thing I like more than word 
puzzles, and that&#39;s showing off how good I am

at word puzzles. But there&#39;s one thing I like 
even more than that: being praised for it by

a beautifully realized narrator with a voice 
like a chocolate beanbag chair. I only wish

there&#39;d been more of Cryptmaster. And that the 
voice actor would rescind his restraining order.

I was gonna give Wuthering Waves a pass for 
the hot anime babes, but then I realized that

a hot anime babe standing around being boring is 
worse than a drab character doing it because it&#39;s

a waste of perfectly good booty shorts. I&#39;d call 
it mind-numbingly, soul-crushingly repetitive and

obtuse, but it&#39;s a gacha game, so it&#39;d probably 
take that as a compliment for a job well done.

Look, I don&#39;t need to explain 
this one. You know Suicide Squad:

Kill The Justice League sucks balls, I know it 
sucks balls, and apparently its creators know

better than any of us that it sucks balls &#39;cos 
they&#39;re already shutting down support for it.

No reason we can&#39;t give it one last kick 
in the bum as it&#39;s heading out the door,

though. Should&#39;ve stopped after the 
first word of your title, dickmunch.

The big indie title fight for me this year was 
&quot;best Soulslike where you play a cute animal,&quot;

with the final round coming down to Nine Sols 
or Another Crab&#39;s Treasure. Both good games, but

Crab&#39;s has the edge for me because it didn&#39;t smash 
me over the head with excessive difficulty and I

understood everything that happened in the plot. 
And that certainly is innovative for a Soulslike.

Another big winner from the &quot;games I 
completely forgot I played this year&quot; stable,

V Rising really should have asked itself, 
&quot;What is the principle activity performed

by our badass vampire protagonist?&quot; 
And when the answer came back not

as &quot;kicking ass and drinking blood&quot; 
but &quot;wallpapering and menacing random

trees and bits of rock,&quot; that was the first 
time they should&#39;ve gone back to formula.

Stripping the shitty Assassin&#39;s Creed part out 
of Assassin&#39;s Creed: Black Flag to leave only

the superlative pirating gameplay? How could 
you fuck that up? Well, Ubisoft&#39;ll find a way.

Jeff Goldblum voice. What you do is you make 
it a boring live service crafter and pare the

gameplay down until it&#39;s basically a &quot;playing 
with toy boats in the bath&quot; simulator except

you have to grind up popping bubbles for an hour 
before you&#39;re allowed to turn on the hot tap.

This might be a surprise pick, but I realized 
looking back over my 2024 reviews that Pacific

Drive was the game I most wanted to play 
again. It&#39;s a beautifully crafted mix of

exploration, mystery, satisfying short-term 
achievements, interesting long-term ones,

exciting car chases, and extreme 
survival broken up with nice,

meditative car maintenance sessions. It is a 
dad game, but I&#39;m a dad, and it&#39;s my list. I

officially gave up on representing mainstream 
tastes around the time I played the following.

There was only ever going to be one winner 
in the blandness competition. A boring,

generic, unfocused Ubisoft open world 
game with the Star Wars license;

that&#39;s like the perfect combination of Balatro 
jokers that send your point multipliers to the

fucking moon. Ubisoft really are in the shit 
right now. Maybe this will be the catalyst

that makes them restructure and become 
better people. And then take me away on

a rainbow chariot to the land of sherbet 
blowjobs &#39;cos now I am fucking dreaming.

We never seem to fucking learn. You don&#39;t 
put a layer of vegemite on the bottom of

an ice cream sundae, and you don&#39;t 
make multiplayer-focused sequels to

established single-player franchises. 
That&#39;s strike one against South Park:

Snow Day! It&#39;s also flimsy, boring, poorly 
designed, and way too fucking short. I mean,

if you&#39;re going to bugger me senseless 
with a blunt instrument, at least use

something long and sturdy that would make for an 
interesting conversation with the proctologist.
